name: Chapter 4: Scaling Amazon EC2
description: Flashcards explaining EC2 Auto Scaling features using real-world pizza shop metaphors.

cards.front: You want your EC2 instances to automatically adjust based on customer traffic. What AWS feature enables this?
cards.back: Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling provides scalability by automatically adjusting the number of instances based on demand, helping optimize cost and performance.
cards.example: A news website adds more EC2 instances during peak hours and scales down at night using Auto Scaling.
cards.mnemonic: More mouths? More ovens. Fewer mouths? Fewer bills.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Skills and Best Practices for Cloud Support Associates

glossary.definition: AWS service that adjusts compute capacity automatically to maintain performance and cost-efficiency.
The ability to automatically grow or shrink resources in response to changing demand.

cards.front: You want to add EC2 instances when traffic spikes and remove them when demand drops. Which scaling method supports this?
cards.back: Dynamic scaling uses real-time metrics like CPU utilization to adjust EC2 instance counts up or down automatically as traffic changes.
cards.example: An e-commerce site scales out during flash sales and scales back afterward using dynamic scaling.
cards.mnemonic: React in real-time—no cold pizzas, no cold profits.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Skills and Best Practices for Cloud Support Associates

glossary.definition: Scaling EC2 instances based on real-time performance metrics.

cards.front: You know your EC2 usage will spike every Friday night. What Auto Scaling strategy should you use?
cards.back: Predictive scaling uses historical patterns to schedule instance scaling actions in advance, improving responsiveness and reducing lag.
cards.example: A media company schedules scaling events every Friday for their livestream platform based on previous demand.
cards.mnemonic: If the crowd’s predictable, schedule the sizzle.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Skills and Best Practices for Cloud Support Associates

glossary.definition: Scaling EC2 instances based on anticipated demand from historical trends.

cards.front: How can you configure Auto Scaling to ensure you always run at least one instance, aim for two, and never exceed four?
cards.back: Set the Auto Scaling group’s minimum to 1, desired to 2, and maximum to 4 to define the lower, target, and upper limits for EC2 instance scaling.
cards.example: A web app sets its Auto Scaling group with min=1, desired=2, max=4 to handle variable traffic with controlled limits.
cards.mnemonic: Set the floor, aim for the sweet spot, and cap the ceiling.

glossary.definition: The lowest number of EC2 instances maintained at all times.
The target number of EC2 instances Auto Scaling tries to maintain.
The upper limit on EC2 instances Auto Scaling can launch.
